hate me for this so i reminded her that i let sammy and his family move in which is something her own family refused to do so she should start with shamingblaming them for not taking their own son and i worked in child psychology and i want to add this to your defense as a 16yo and a dependent she had zero control over this change in her life it is great that she seems to be handling it maturely and it is entirely reasonable that you and your wife expect her to handle it maturely but it is always worth noting that the parents made the decision and to her it is just something that happened to her i think letting her have her room as a truly private space is a good idea even if it does look like she is sulking being antisocial or being selfish in there kids sort of need a way to feel like they have control over parts of their life or they are at risk of developing fatalism and with it feelings of impotence also a 16 year old may seem pretty adult but their brains are still growing certain parts such as emotional maturity and this includes her capacity for empathy sharing belongings should be her choice because if she has no choice in the matter she has no chance to grow by making the decision without being able to choose sharing or selfishness her only choice will be whether or not she feels like a victim a martyr or a forgotten nobody and she might choose selfishness and it is reasonable to consider that the wrong choice but teenagers fuck up and you kind of have to let them turn those fuck ups into learning moments you should also know that the trauma of losing a house and parents splitting may result in tumultuous feelings that lead a person to test whether the people around you care about you it could easily be part of why their family seems volatile about this issue and your bil may be unconsciously creating guilty feelings in your wife by making her feel tested she will need your support too you might find good resources in books about setting healthy boundaries with your loved ones

nta there is a couple of things going on here your bils twin daughters are sisters and their purchases are usually shared between each other because their parents purchased them they have likely grown up in a household where they have to share everything having your bil and wife try to make the best of this situation and pretend they have sort of combined families can erase the usual boundaries for the nieces "our house is your house" is never meant to be literal and most people know this implicitly not everyone does though depending on how things were done in their own home children going through divorce and homelessness are not in the best place to observe boundaries either your daughter did not grow up like this she is not accustomed to people rifling through her belongings without permission even if she were expected to share the things you and your wife provide this makeup set was purchased by her with her own money and therefore should not be shared unless she chooses to share it your nieces are old enough to respect your previous requests for daughter's privacy and to deal with whatever hurt feelings they have about not being allowed to touchuse things that do not belong to them i understand that they are dealing with a lot of stress from their parents separating and becoming homeless but your real problem is their father and aunt are encouraging this behavior you might want to really talk to your daughter about being more sensitive to their situation in detail about how difficult and scary this level of uncertainty can be and how much she might appreciate kindness in that situation empathy and compassion for situations worse than your own is a life skill that said the lock should stay and you should continue to support your daughter your wife's family are guests in your home being family does not mean they do not have to observe boundaries nor does it mean they are entitled to use other people's belongings without permission i second the person who suggested the girls get full access to your wife's belongings since she is so keen to share meanwhile enjoy the silent treatment while it lasts

nta this is the age where they need to be learning respect for others and their belongings sharing is a voluntary decision i sometimes share my car with my brother if they take it without permission that is grand theft auto sharing is not some sort of automatic default of what is mine is yours what is yours is mine one thing you may not be considering here is that twins sometimes have a weaker conception of personal property and other specific kinds of boundaries than other kids i would hope that their dad would have addressed this by 18 but it is possible he did not my twin brother and i were like this much of what we had as kids was ours not mine or his especially things like clothes when we did laundry we basically made a big pile of everything our size and did one for me one for you because it was too hard to figure out what belonged to who and writing names on all the tags was too much of a hassle having an older brother who was not a twin and enforced more conventional boundaries helped a lot as well as friends cousins etc keep in mind that their tendency to just treat her stuff as their property may simply extend from the fact that this is how they have always interacted with each other which is an extension of the world treating twins and an interchangeable unit i am not saying this is a reason to tolerate that behavior keep the lock i am saying it should inform a certain amount of empathy in going about correcting that behavior like i said 18 might be a bit late to learn that but you can try
